title: Will voter turnout for the 2019 European Parliament elections set a record low?
preds: On balance, well conscious about the 50:50 tendency of this question overall and the cognitive dissonance to my prediction, I have gone through the material, once again, and I still cannot fit into my head why there would be a new record low. Does not fit the bill, I cannot get my head around it, but my prediction is too obvious to my mind (and I am more pro EU than not, fitting, huh?), hence the pounding in my head ;-) ...and I know the tricks our minds play on ourselves, regardless of ourselves. Well, it seems that I, at the end of the day, like to take calculated risks! And my body does not.

Adjusting: I strengthen my prediction that the voter turnout in the election of EU Parliament will not set a record low. One reason is time period as it is only a couple days left until election, the likelihood that something highly unexpected will happen and impact the voters’ participation is very limited. Second, as UK is one of the biggest countries in the EU, its people participation has a huge impact towards the final turnout of the EU election. Also, as it was mentioned in the previous analysis, British usually have one of the lowest turnout in the EU election. Even though, in opposite when I assumed, Britain will take part in EU elections, it does not increase the likelihood of lowest turnout. Responding to many British people “mood”, the EU election this year has a bigger weight than any previous ones. Lots of people  the participation in it see as one more EU referendum and a chance to show for, firstly, Britain politicians that they want to stay in EU. Based on previous arguments, I assume that the voters’ turnout will not be the lowest.

Update: In my initial forecast, I speculated that Denmark would be one of the countries to hold the EP election in conjunction other elections, thus increasing voter participation. However, this will not be the case as Denmark's general election will be held on July 5th. It was the hypothesis that joined elections would boost a slumping voter turnout, as it would bring voters who are otherwise not engaged with the EU to the voting booths. Hence, Denmark's participation rate will likely not increase as predicted. In my initial prediction, I also assumed that the UK would not be partaking in the EU elections, but it is shaping up to be one more British EP election. Normally, voter turnout in the UK has been lover than the average European participation, but it has been suggested that the current Brexit chaos will bring out voters from both the ‘remain’ and the ‘hard-Brexit’ side will participate in increased numbers to showcase their respective feelings about UK’s continued involvement with the EU. Potentially, if voter turnout increases significantly, the UK participation could add positively to the overall voter participation. 
Overall, surveys have shown that 48% of European citizens believe that 'their voice counts in the EU', which is an increase from past years. Yet, only 43 % of eligible voters respond that they are certain that they will vote. This is not an immediate increase from past years’ participation, however, the increased commitment to EU could indicate that participation will not continue its free-fall. This is supported by the reports that an increasing amount of European citizens report that they consider their European identity as important as their national identity. 
On the basis of the above, I still believe that the elections will not set a record low, however, I keep probability at 15%.

I assume that there’s a 15% chance of voter turnout for the 2019 European parliament elections to set a record low. Below are the major reasons explaining my point of view:  -	Since 1979 the voter turnout has been decreasing from 61.99% to 42.61% (the results of the elections of 2014). However, between 2004 elections (45.47%) and 2009 (42.97) the decrease was 2.5% and the same number was reduced to only 0.36% between 2009 and 2014. Hence, drastic changes cannot be expected for the 2019 European Parliament elections. -	Nowadays there are several major issues that will encourage the voters to participate in elections. According to the report “public opinion in the EU regions”, analyzing the surveys carried out in the member states of the EU, states that the EU citizens claim that the major concerns facing the EU are: healthcare system, unemployment, the education system, the environment, immigration, crime, economic situation and people and/or business going away from the region.  Even though some of the problems have been in place in 2009 and 2014 as well, the survey indicates that the difference between the survey conducted in 2012 and 2015 isn’t that big. Hence, there are problems that are still significant in the lives of the EU citizens, even though some of the issues that had been identified before have been improved. Additionally, I would add topics like Brexit, the tense relations between the EU and US and the EU and Russia as drivers to participate in the European parliament elections. -	The whole process of Brexit has brought into the spotlight the importance of the European Union. I might be too optimistic, but I believe that the EU citizens won’t allow the voter turnout to be the lowest now and will demonstrate sympathy/loyalty towards the union.  Sources:  http://ec.europa.eu/commfrontoffice/publicopinion/index.cfm/survey/getsurveydetail/instruments/flash/surveyky/2219 http://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/in-the-past/previous-elections

Although the EU is making efforts to fight voter apathy and encourage younger voters to come out to the ballots, the factors that have been in play for the past decades haven’t changed. Voters have a greater interest in their national elections than in EU parliamentary elections because they do not agree on the direction the EU is taking.   Steps have been made to increase voter turnout through get-out-to-vote campaigns sponsored by two major EU parties while some nations have made voting compulsory; however, these efforts have not made a major impact on the number of voters who participate. Therefore, it is likely that voter turnout for the 2019 European Parliament will remain low.   Sources:

This forecast is just an initial estimate. I looked at data from past European Union parliamentary elections, and found the average voting rate was 52.14%, so I’m using that as a base rate. Another way of framing the question is "Will voter turnout for the 2019 European Parliament elections fall below 42.61%?" Compared to the base rate of 52.14%, I have some doubts about low voter turnouts. Still, I could be wrong because there is a lot I don’t know or understand yet about the situation. Also, is it possible that voter turnout reaches an all-time high? With the events of Brexit and much uncertainty happening in the world, is it reasonable to assume many voters could come out in droves to determine the fate of the European Union? Some questions to consider as the situation unfolds: For either answer (yes or no), what would be some indicators of either event occurring? What is the context the question is being asked in? What are the key assumptions underlying the question or discussion? What are the key drivers of voter turnout in this instance? I will try to update this forecast when appropriate.

Update: the UK's participation in the election is cause for slightly adjusting the forecast. They have historically had below-average voter turn-outs, and this was a consideration in earlier forecasts which had expected that the UK would not participate in the EU Parliamentary election. However, given the current political climate in the UK and public discontent with Brexit, it does seem probable that more will head to the polling booths to have their say (for one last time). That being said, and the reason for the slight increase in this forecast, these is also the possibility that Brits refrain from voting, knowing that Brexit is looming, which could bring down the EU-wide average.  All this places emphasis on the role of the UK in this forecast. But overall, due to reasons laid out earlier, it is still considered highly unlikely that the upcoming parliamentary election will set a record low voter turnout.

The UK local election of yesterday has been greatly affected by the Brexit question. There had been suggestions that dissatisfaction over the lack of Brexit progress would mean a drop in support for the Conservative Party, but that the voting would be a proxy poll on Brexit and turn out would be higher than normal as people would made Brexit protest votes/  In the event turn out has on average been at about the same level as most local elections; it appears to have been a bit higher in places where there is a majority for Remain and lower in places where there is a majority to Leave. Some commentators have explained this by saying that there was no obvious party for Leave supporters to vote for, while there were two parties that's policy was to Remain (the LibDems and the Greens). They say that UKIP is no longer a viable party, and so Leave voters did not vote for it and it only fielded candidates in 25% of constituencies.  
While its true that the Brexit Party, which did not put up candidates in the local election, is now more popular than UKIP (but of course got no votes) this seems more like an excuse than a reason. Only a month or so ago UKIP (the original Leave party) was polling at 11% and presumably was considered by 11% of voters to be a credible party, the fact that it put up fewer candidates and has lost most of its seats is more to do with its Leave message being unpopular with people who actually go out to vote. This supports the view that Leave voters are now not very motivated to actually vote. The LibDems and the Greens got a lot more seats in this local election than previously which tends to show that Remain voters are (as suspected) more motivated to go out to vote. 
Obviously a local election has in theory nothing to do with Brexit, the government or the EU, but in practice people tend to vote for parties. So the Conservatives and Labour parties lost a lot of support in the local elections because voters were not happy with their handling of Brexit.
One other factor that is difficult to establish the implications of is that there was also a large increase of "independents" elected (e.g. candidates not running on a party ticket), Its difficult to know why people voted for the independents without knowing what they all said their manifestos were. Most that I have seen were about dissatisfaction with local services, about the political parties ignoring voters and tended to be more right wing than left wing. My guess (and the numbers lost by Conservatives and won by Independents) is that they were voted for mainly by former Conservative Leave voters, so that might well be where many of the Leave supports went. So how will this affect the EU elections? There will be two more significant parties taking part in the EU elections; ChangeUK a Remain party and the Brexit Party for Leave. The question is will their presence  increase turn out or just take votes away from other parties that took part in the local elections? My guess is that the Brexit Party will mainly attract voters who in the local election voted for UKIP, Labour,  the Conservatives or those who voted Independant and a few people who did not vote in the local elections thereby raising the turn out figure a little. ChangeUK will mostly attract people who voted for the LibDems or Greens in the local elections, but also some votes from Conservative and Labour Remainers (who don't like the LibDems and Greens). I don't think it will attract very many people who did not bother to vote in the local elections. Because most voters will think any MEPs elected will make little difference and that the only point of voting at all is to protest against or support Brexit I expect the vote share of the Conservative and Labour Parties will be even lower than they were in the local elections.  The overall outcome is likely to be a small rise in the turn out in the UK for the EU elections, which is likely to be cancelled out in other EU countries as the decline in turn out continues.

The UK Labour Party yesterday confirmed its Brexit position. This will surely affect turnout by Labour Party Members and supporters for the EU Parliamentary Elections. 
The Labour position is that it will support a Public Vote on a Conservative version of Brexit, but will not support a Public Vote on a Labour version of Brexit. I don't know if Labour voters will have spotted the logic of this. A Conservative version of Brexit could only pass the UK Parliament if the Conservative Government was able to get a majority of MPs to back it. If a majority of MPs had just voted thru a Conservative version of Brexit those same MPs would hardly be likely to then vote to first hold a Public Vote on the deal that they have voted for. If the Government had got its Brexit Bill thru Parliament the UK would leave the EU, which means it would be too late to hold a Public Vote on it.
If somehow the Conservative Government could be persuaded to support a Labour version of Brexit and there was a majority of MPs who would vote for it, then according to the Labour Policy there would be no need to have a Public Vote. 
So a "Conservative" version of Brexit would be opposed by Labour, who would demand a Public Vote. If there were enough MPs to vote it thru it would not matter what Labour demanded because it would be passed anyway without a Public Vote. If there were not enough MPs to to pass the Consevative version of Brexit it would not happen and so no Public Vote is needed.  
So in short the Labour policy is pointless because Labour would never have the number of MPs to demand a Public Vote on a Conservative version of Brexit that was able to pass in parliament.
As 2/3 of Labour voters support Remain, and up to 80% of Labour members are in favour of a Public Vote on any Brexit deal, the cunning plan by the Labour leadership to try and appeal to Leavers by saying they would like to push thru a Labour version of Brexit, and to appeal to Remainers by saying that it might be possible to avoid Brexit by having a Public Vote on a Conservative Brexit, does not really work. Many of Labour Leave voters might have been happy with the Conservative Brexit, which Labour is ruling out. And most of the Labour Remain voters will be upset because Labour is ruling out stopping Brexit. 
So its clear that few Labour voters would get what they want, so why would they bother to vote for Labour candidates for the EU Parliamentory Elections? 
Their logical choice is to vote for a party that clearly supports Brexit or a party that clearly supports Remain or to refrain from voting at all.  https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-48099901

Admittedly, my view is from across the pond, but it seems the expense of bureaucracy outweighs the benefits.  Evem Germany is economically slowing. I  do not belive they view the Parliament as a critical problem-solving force. It simply does not matter as much as many had hoped.

Forecast Update #4: I'd like to reinforce the argument, I made in my original forecast from March 4, 2019 with regard to the Brexit and its impact on voter turnout. See there for more details, however, in short: Brexit might have shown both advocates and opponents of the EU that this election matters. One of my arguments was that the traditional low voter turnout in the UK and its relatively big population would fall away due to the fact that - from my original point of view - the UK would have not taken part in these elections. Thus, the likelihood of record low decreased. However, now it seems that the UK will participate. Even though the logical conclusion would be now to raise the likelihood of a historic low voter turnout again, I further reduced it as of 2%. Now estimating a 7% likelihood of historical low voter turnout. This is due to two reasons: Both advocates and opponents of Brexit in the UK will use the upcoming elections to stress their point. The highly politicized Brexit will most likely increase voter turnout on the island. Furthermore, arguably, the chaos aligned with Brexit and the dramatic consequences for the UK most likely will lead to a higher voter turnout on the continent as well, due to the fact that more people consumed EU related news in the context of Brexit. Voters that did not care so far about the EU and its parliamentary elections might have realized its value now - or respectively, came to the conclusion now that Brexit might be a good idea and want to use the EU elections to support corresponding aspirations. Either way, voter turnout will increase.  Thus, in combination with the arguments made in my original forecast, as well as in the update from March 8, I estimate a 7% likelihood of historical low voter turnout.

UPDATE 24.04.2019 After following the debate between the users @1291 and @Anneinak, I have decided to further decrease my likelihood for a new low record to 2% (I would change it to 2,5% if possible). As far as I can judge, these forecasters and other forecasters seem to share my opinion (at least to some extend).  However, I would like to shift attention to other issues which could impact the forecast at hand: 
- Do anti-EU parties (such as the AfD, former FN or the PVV) encourage their voters to participate in the EU elections (as a tactical move to increase their influence on European policy-making)?
- Or do they actively encourage their voter bases to avoid the EU elections in order to undermine its legitimacy?
- Are they able to successfully mobilize their voters to go to vote? 
- How did they act in the last EU elections?  These questions require extensive research and therefore won't be answered soon. However, regarding their importance, it will be the next step in my assessment of the future EU election voter turnout. As a result, I will likely postpone my research about the correlation of national with EU voter turnouts of past elections.

Making this forecast comes down to weighing a continued trend of voter apathy and a general trend of lessened voter engagement across the world versus the chance that a spike in civic engagement leads to a rally for voter turnout. This election will be the first EP vote since the Brexit referendum, and engagement with the Union has become a more prominently featured topic in both local governance and the news media. Initially while trying to answer this question, I was tempted to pull data from local elections, such as those in Italy and France, that indicate that despite a rise in more populist candidates voter engagement has continued to slide. However, these elections have a much different focus than MEP elections and the interests in one do not necessarily translate over to another. Further, as a general trend the decline in voter turnout itself has declined in more recent elections: That is to say the margin by which elections have less turnout than the prior EP election is shrinking. With these combined factors, it appears highly likely that if any year would be the year for an upset, it would be 2019.

This forecast will be combining historic data about the general and each state’s voter turnout and combine it with survey data to assesses if the turnout rate will increase or decrease for 2019.  The general turnout has been decreasing since the first EU parliamentary election in 1979. From a participation rate of 61,99% in 1979 to 42,61% in 2014 (an -31,3% decrease in total).  This might seem high but shouldn’t be overemphasized regarding the actual slowly and steadily decreasing turnout development in the periods of 1979 to 1994 with -8,6% and from 2004 to 2014 with -6,3%. It shows that the actual turnout decline rate itself is decreasing. Furthermore, it almost came to a halt in the period from 2009 to 2014 with only a -0,01% decline of voters participating in the EU election. There are two periods which represent exemptions. Between 1994 and 1999 there is a peak decline of -12,6%. This could be explained through Austria’s, Sweden’s and Finland’s shared scepticism about an EU membership, thus, representing an extreme case. The other major decline is between 1999 to 2014 with -8,2% within 4 years. The reason may be the largest expansion of the Union by welcoming 10 new members (in comparison of 1 to 3 new members in between elections). Some of the new members represent former Soviet republics which may explain the low turnout from these countries due to their lack in experience to hold democratic elections, as well as the unfamiliarity to/lack of trust in such elections by its citizen. However, again, this drop should be seen as an extreme case which doesn’t apply for the upcoming election. To conclude, regarding the fact that the trend almost stopped and that there was no expansion of the EU, it is unlikely that there will be a drastic drop in the voter turnout. The last decrease of merely -0,01% means that the trend could even change for the first time in the EU’s history.  To assess if this might happen, the forecast at hand will estimate if the voter turnout in each member state is likely to increase or decrease by examining various aspects. First of all, the past development of each member states’ voter turnout will be consulted in order to estimate the likely future progress. Second, it is important to assess the awareness of the upcoming election as this is a variable which reflects the possible participation rate of European citizens across the EU. The used data is from the “Parlamenter 2018” poll’s questions QA8 “How likely are you to vote in these elections?” (the 10-point scale will be summarized in this way: 1 to 5 = unlikely to participate in election vs. 6 to 10 = likely to participate in election) and QA7 “How interested or not are you in these elections?”. In absence of data from previous surveys this variable will solely be based on the 2018 survey data. Third, the overall opinion of EU citizens towards the European Union will be assessed by using the Eurobarometer’s variable “Image of the European Union” and its results in the last 2 surveys (03/2018; 11/2018). This forecast assumes, that voters who give the EU a bad rating are less likely to attend to its election as going to the polls is connected to costs (time spent, distance to ballot, etc.). The group “Neutral” doesn’t allow for any clear estimation if voters in this group will participate or not (the group: “Don’t know” will be excluded). Another aspect would be the public support of an exit referendum in their respective countries. Unfortunately, the Eurobarometer variable “Membership to the EU” cannot be used due to missing updates (last update was in 2011). National polls concerning a referendum support cannot be used neither due to the lack of data for some member states. However, the “Parlamenter 2018”-survey contains relevant data in question QA3s through asking citizens how they would vote if a referendum would take place the next day (only the answers for leave and remain will be included). This approach is interesting as it allows us to assume that citizens who support an exit-referendum likely won’t participate in the EU election due to participation cost. For this purpose, only the leave and remain votes will be counted. Again, this forecast will use solely the 2018 data due to the absence of this question in previous (and relatively recent) surveys. Another examined aspect in this forecast addresses the potential combination of national general or local elections with the EU election. The underlying rational is that combined elections decrease the threshold for the EU election and, as a result, increase participation. Additionally, it will be checked if states have a compulsory voting policy for the upcoming election. It’s effect on the turnout has to be estimated based on country specific circumstances. A future update of this forecast might include the voter turnout base rates for the respective national/federal elections in each member state. It wasn’t initially used due to its low priority in comparison to the used variables above as national/federal elections apply to other voter dynamics than supranational elections due to their proximity effect on voters.  Each countries likelihood to increase or decrease its voter turnout will be categorized in 5 labels: a) Very likely to decrease; b) Likely to decrease; c) Stable; d) Likely to increase; e) Very likely to increase. The detailed assessment of each state can be found below.  Number of States with likely or very likely decreasing voter turnout (combined number of registered voters): 5 (65,5 Million registered voters)  Number of States with a likely stable voter turnout (combined number of registered voters): 6 (109,6 Million registered voters)  Number of States with a likely or very likely increasing voter turnout (combined number of registered voters): 17 (216,9 Million registered voters) Overall conclusion: The general election turnout almost stopped its decline with a merely -0,01% in 2014. This forecast analysed the likelihood of each country’s voter turnout to remain, increase or decrease in order to assess if the general EU trend will remain or change its direction. As a result, it seems very unlikely that the next EU election will set a new low record with 17 states likely increasing their voter turnout, as well as additional 6 states remaining a stable level, against 5 states who are likely to decrease their voter turnout. Involving the constituency size of each bloc clarifies the situation further. The combined bloc of states who will likely increase or remain their turnout results comprises of 326,5 Million registered voters in comparison to the 65,5 Million registered voters’ bloc which will likely decrease its turnout. That is a ratio of almost 5:1. However, this doesn’t mean that all voters in a state’s constituency will go to vote, but it indicates the underlying dynamic of expected voter participation across the European Union. In the case that all countries categorized as “stable” will decrease their voter turnout the constituency comparison changes to: 216,9 Mil. vs. 175,1 Mil. registered voters. In the case that countries who are only “likely” to increase will fall into the “stable” category the number relation changes to: 99,4 Mil. vs. 65,5 Mil. (or 175,1 Mil.) registered voters. This represents a very high threshold of conditions which have to happen before a new low record will be realized. As a result, the likelihood of such a new record is assessed to be only 5%.  (Annotation: the sub-conclusion may speak of (e.g.) Austrians which implies that the data displays all voter opinions in Austria. However, the used data below is derived mostly from surveys and polls and, thus, doesn’t allow for such generalizations. The use of generalizing language merely represents a simplification in order to minimize the overall length! Nonetheless, the conclusions are based on survey and poll data.)   AUSTRIA: Very likely to increase - It is very likely that voter turnout for Austria will increase regarding the average increase of participation (+4,8%), the relative high likelihood to go to vote stated by survey respondents and a majority who is interested in the elections. Additionally, Austrians seem to be unwilling to support a referendum and their image of the EU is fairly high (also increasing by 11%).

Every EU Parliamentary election has had a lower turnout than the previous one so going purely by the previous trend the simple conclusion would be 100% Yes. So the question is what would lead you to think that the trend was about to reverse?  There have been no new members since 2014 and no country has left, so its the same electorate. If the UK had left, as the UK has had a lower than average turnout in the past, it would be expected that the turnout would have been higher than if the UK takes part. I estimate that (other things being equal) that the UK not taking part would have raised the EU average by about 0,5% (the UK's turnout has been about 7% below the EU average and UK voters make up about 12% of EU voters) if these figures had applied in 2014 it would have raised the EU turnout above the 2009 turnout. So it could have been expected that something similar could happen in 2019 if the UK did not take part.  Countries other than the UK have EU issues, particularly regarding immigration from outside the EU and dispersal of immigrants (and asylum seekers) between EU countries, but my feeling is that EU voters do not see a very direct link between EU policies and MEPs. EU voters tend to see national elections and national governments as having more influence on EU policies than MEPs do. (I found that in 2016 many UK voters denied that the UK had taken part in the 2014 European Parliamentary Elections. I imagine in other EU countries with low EU election turnouts voters are similarly indifferent to who is elected to the EU Parliament. )   I have not noticed a greater interest among people in EU (excluding the UK) in the 2019 EU elections than in 2014.  That said the trend curve for turnout does make it appear that the low point could be close (2014 to 2019 the drop was only 0.36%).
So the question does seems to be of how likely it is that the UK will take part?
The UK will take part unless the Brexit WA is carried thru the UK parliament before 23rd May. I don't think that Mrs May will get the DUP and all the ERG section of her Conservative Party to vote for the WA and even then that might not produce a majority, so it would need Labour MPs to vote for the WA. The current talks between Labour and Conservatives appears to me to be a sham. Over the weekend some detail of what exactly was being discussed was made public. 
Regarding the most important issue; future trade the discussions appear to be almost exactly the same wish list that is in the Brexit Political Declaration. i.e. a customs arrangement, that's like a customs union, but is not a customs union, that gives completely free trade with no tariffs or quotas, or rules of origin restrictions between the UK and EU, some sort of closeness between the EU single market rules, that does not stop the UK having different rules if it wants, but at the same times are accepted by the EU as being the same, has no freedom of movement, and allows the UK to conduct its own FTAs with 3rd countries. I am sure anything agreed would include lots of warm words like "hope", "aim", "close to" "desire" "objective". Presumably this wish list will "hope" to solve the Irish Border issue. To me this just sound like more magical thinking. If what is being described was implemented what would stop the UK doing a FTA with (say) China so that China could export car parts tariff free to the UK and then the UK re-export them to the EU tariff free, quota free and rules of origin free? Or a FTA with the USA so that the UK offered a backdoor route get US agricultural products into the EU (via that open border with Ireland).  Agreeing such a Political Declaration might look like Brexit progress by is unlikely to appeal to Labour MPs, because they know that the UK government has done all it can so far to avoid allowing parliament to have a say in Brexit, and once a Brexit WA is passed by parliament there is nothing that would prevent the government agreeing any EU trade agreement it wanted without parliament having any say. (Parliament only got a say over the WA because the Supreme Court forced it.)
Note: parliament has not had any involvement in the trade agreements that Liam Fox has been doing to replace the FTAs that the UK will lose (with 3rd countries) when the UK leaves the EU. Fox has said his intention was to just "roll over" existing FTA between the 3rd countries and EU, but that has not been possible and the FTAs between the 3rd counties and UK will be different to ones they had with the EU.  So there is no guarantee that parliament would be able to block or change a FTA between the UK and EU post-Bexit. So Labour's leverage comes now before the WA is passed, after the WA is passed is too late. I assume they can see that and will not agree a blind Brexit. 
So my conclusion is that the UK will not agree the WA before 23rd May and will take part in the EU elections.
Which brings us to the turnout change in the UK. I think other forecasters are right to be skeptical about poll answers on how likely people are to vote in these elections. Without going in to all the evidence it seems that Pro-Brexit supporters are less likely to see the EU parliamentary as a "must vote" occasion than Anti-Brexit supporters (Anti-Brexit demos and online petitions have attracted around ten times the support of Pro-Brexit ones). Many voters who habitually vote Conservative or Labour will not agree with their parties EU policy (or non-policy) some (maybe as many as 50% of them) will switch their vote to a clearer Pro or Anti Brexit party, but just as many will not bother to vote at all. The EU elections are seem by most UK voters as a rare chance to vote for the party that has policies you agree with, rather than the usual case in first-past-the-post where you vote for the party with the policies you think will cause the least harm. But overall I think the turnout will increase but the increase in Pro and Anti Brexit supporters will largely be offset by people who will claim not voting is itself a protest. So I don't think an increase in UK votes will increase the total EU turnout.

Interest in EU heightened around continent

European election turnout has trended to long term decline, from 61% in 1979 to 43% in 2014. Despite this, there are good reasons to believe this trend will not continue in this year's election.  1. In 2014, the turnout was fractionally higher than in 2009, indicating that we may have reached the "floor" of European political apathy at around the 43% mark
2. Brexit has turned EU politics into daily news, which means that the EU is top of mind for more Europeans
3. Nigel Farage's launch of the "Brexit Party" has guaranteed an interesting ideological struggle around these European elections that will increase UK turnout in EU elections (one of the larger EU countries) as the closest thing the country will get to a "redo" of the Brexit vote. News coverage of this will be beamed to TVs across Europe making the election more "top of mind" for media companies and for people across Europe. Under similar conditions, US elections recently reached far higher levels of turnout than those observed a decade ago. 
4. Polling data is showing that the fiasco of Brexit has already caused other Europeans to view the EU in a more favorable light, which will act as a counter balance to electoral apathy, at least for the timeframe of these elections. 
5. Google search data for "European Union" is trending higher in the major European countries than at was at this point in the run up to the 2014 European elections
6. Re-alignment of political blocs with the major transnational parliamentary "groups" is introducing "new news" across the continent that will be an added incentive for people to get interested
7. The perception that the EU parliament is relatively impotent as a body will continue to act as a drag on these positive turnout trends, however, as previously noted, 43% may represent an apathy "floor", so this is probably not enough to actually drag turnout lower, it just means that trends that could push it higher will have less of an impact than we've seen around other controversial elections (e.g. Clinton Trump). In other words, turnout won't hit a new low, but it won't hit a new high either. 
8. No new members have been added to the EU since 2007, so the electorate is stable for the purposes of this forecast.  For these reasons it seems highly improbable that the EU turnout will reach a record low, however, long term apathy trends cannot be completely ignored.

Updating my forecasting: 
Theresa May applied for yet another extension until the 30th of June. So now the UK are officially planning to participate in the EP election, which I thought they wouldn't. But part of the application says that the extension should end before June 30th if a deal is agreed upon in the UK parliament. Judging by how messy things have been going until now, I don't see parliament suddenly agreeing on anything, but who knows really? If the UK end up participating, this poll from the end of February suggest that participation will be at 43%, which is actually higher than the participation rate in 2014 [1]. Asking people if they want to participate in something usually gives a higher rates than those who actually participate, so I'm not really convinced by that number.   As you might expect, the poll reports that there is a big difference between those who voted for remain vs. leave. The polarisation between remain and leave is confirmed by this poll analysis (which is from a remarkably good non-partisan website called whatukthinks.org run by something called "The economic and social research council".) New major factor/hypothesis: though EU voter turnout is clearly in a secular decline (Western civ peak ~1800 AD - 2100 AD end), the rate of decline is mediated by currency strength. When USD is strong and others weak, like in the 1990s, European voters unplugged in droves. When USD is weak and others/Euro strong, like in the 2000s, the decline in Euro voting slowed significantly. Present day, we're just off a high in the ~17 year USD cycle, meaning depressed EU voter interest and a big sequential drop in turnout (-400 ± 225 bps, < 40%). Would explain why Brussels' bureaucrats are so keen to juice participation.

The average percentage of participation had reached its peak (61,99%) in 1979, going down in 1984 (58,98), 1989 (58,41%), 1994 (56,67%) until the huge breakdown in 1999 at 49,51%. In 2004 it reached 45,57% and 42,97% in 2009. In the last 2014 elections the result have been the worst, with an attendance of only 42,61%, but very similar to the 2009 results which doesn’t make me forecast a huger declining.	  https://www.wired.it/attualita/politica/2014/05/23/elezioni-europee-affluenza/ http://www.europarl.europa.eu/elections2014-results/en/election-results-2014.html
The lower and lower turnout level could be due to a lack of efficiency and action power perceived by the populations, especially after/during episodes like the economic crisis in 2008 and the refugee crisis. In my view, a huge role is played by the populist anti-European parties that have raised in the last decade in Europe, spread everywhere and founded consensus at the national elections. Those parties have often depicted EU as an enemy that would cared more of bureaucracy and elites than to common lay people, spreading angriness, dissatisfaction and disappointment. Moreover, the recent Brexit referendum and the rise to power of similar movements in other big countries (Trump in USA, Bolsonaro in Brasil), have somehow legitimised those positions.
However, after having hit bottom in 2009 and 2014, I think that this year turnout wouldn’t reach the historical minimums. Even the EU does not good well yet, currently there aren’t emergency situation such as in 2009 or 2014. What I forecast instead is a massive flow of votes for anti-European parties: instead of not voting at all, the populations would prefer to vote them aiming to change EU from the inside and asking their politicians to “take back national sovereignty”, even stopping the process of integration (which already had a setback after Lisbon treaty in 2009, with no more structural treaties).	“While there are significant divides between them on substance, anti-European parties could align with one another tactically in support of a range of ideas: from abolishing sanctions on Russia to blocking the EU’s foreign trade agenda, to pulling the drawbridge up against migration. This would put at risk Europe’s capacity to defend its citizens from external threats at exactly the time when, given global turmoil, it needs to show more resolve, cooperation, and global leadership.” https://www.ecfr.eu/specials/scorecard/the_2019_European_election On the other side, the pro-Europe citizens would feel the urgency of contrasting the rise of euro-sceptics, going to vote for the opposition.

The forecast at hand estimates a 10% likelihood for a new record low in the voting turnout for the EP to realize. It is in fact true, that the EP elections voter turnouts experienced a constant downwards trend. However, it has to be noted that compared to the 2009 elections, the voter turnout in 2014 were only 0.36% lower (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/elections2014-results/de/turnout.html). This difference is rather small and considered too small for this forecast to anticipate a further decrease based upon that, in particular given the fact that the long-term downwards trend (almost 20% between 1979 and 2014) got promoted (among other factors) strongly by the expansion of the EU toward the east where voter turnout has been traditionally lower than in the western countries (https://www.kas.de/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=d3b13d4c-81ad-5926-f2eb-d41cbc81f95b&groupId=252038 and https://blog.datawrapper.de/weekly-chart-turnout/). Since there was no further enlargement since the last elections this factor can be excluded.  Arguably, a too narrow extrapolative focus on this question is furthermore rather counterproductive because it would ignore crucial changes in the context, in which the 2019 EP elections are embedded in. In the aftermath of the 2014 elections many analyses referred to the second order election effect. According to this explanation, EP elections would be perceived as less important and interesting by the electorate than their national counterparts. Therefore, voters would often either not vote or use the vote as as vote on national matters, e.g. to punish their government (http://www.leeds.ac.uk/politics/cbl/int/ele/acsecor.htm) However, the forecast at hand argues that this has changed due to a different political environment, where the EU receives much more attention than it did in the past. Two events in particular are perceived as crucial by this forecast: Brexit and the refugee crisis. The Brexit might have shown both advocates and opponents of the EU that this election matters. The aligned increased media attention in combination with the realization that a further integration is not axiomatic might motivate mobilization and a higher voter turnout on both sides. In the same token, the refugee crisis might mobilize many former non-voters to vote this time, particularly promoted by a broad range of populist parties that put the refugee crisis in a decided EU context (https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/sep/26/populists-immigration-orban-salvini-law-eu-elections). In both cases it has to be noted that in particular populist parties increased voter turns outs in many former national elections in the EU due to their ability to get back non-voters (https://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/fileadmin/files/BSt/Publikationen/GrauePublikationen/ZD__Studie_Populismusbarometer_2018.pdf). This increase in the meaning of the EU in public attention could be already observed by many national elections throughout the last years, where Europe became the central topic, instead of being a side note (e.g. Macron’s 2017 campaign). Building on these changes in the political context of the elections, Europe will be more present among voters and thus more interesting for them. Additional factors decreasing a record low voter turn out probability are the comprehensive and sophisticated electoral grassroots elections campaign by the EU Parliament (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/elections-press-kit/2/this-time-i-m-voting) and the withdrawal of the UK before the elections - a country with a low EU parliament voter turn out and large population (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/elections2014-results/de/turnout.html). Therefore, the forecast assumes only a probability of 10% that this will be the EP election with a record voter turnout low.

While there has been a steady decline in voter turnout since 1979, there are a number of factors to forecast this trend will be broken in the upcoming elections: 1. Voter turnout trends between in 2009 and 2014 steadied with 42.9% and 42.61% — indicating a shift in EU-wide trend since 1979. 2. The United Kingdom’s absence from this year’s vote. Voter turnout in Britain has consistently been below the EU average. In not participating, percentage turnout by default increases — assuming turnout in all other member states is steady.  3. Public focus on the EU and its legitimacy has increased since the 2014 election. Controversies surrounding Brexit have placed the EU in the limelight, and EU citizens are more likely to feel a sense of urgency in exerting their right to vote. This applies to both pro-EU and EU-skeptic voters respectively wishing to secure the legitimacy of the EU, or support a populist movement in the EU parliament.

Despite what the majority of the surveys show, I believe there is a low chance that voters turnout for the 2019 European Parliament elections set a record low. Actually not because, as Politico notes, the European Parliament and European Commission are planning to spend more than €30 million on "get out the vote" advertising and support (which is likely to have only a little impact on the willingness of European citizens to vote). Rather, a number of considerations led me to this conclusion: -The 2014 Election set a record-low 42.61% also because of the particular historical moment when they took place. Indeed, 2014 and the years before represented the end of many traditional parties in the European continent, leading in some countries to the definitive end of the conventional left-right distinction. In the following years, many new parties have gained importance and at the next European Election, they will attempt to convince their voters to sustain them also at the European level.   -Support for the EU is “the highest score ever measured since 1983” according to the Parliament Eurobarometer. -The fact that Europe faced (and is still facing) a wave of populism does not automatically mean that this will turn out in fewer people to vote. In fact, if populists want to change (or destroy) the EU as they usually sustain, they need before to take control of its institutions. For this reason, also populist parties are likely to undertake a strong and intense political campaign. In doing so, they could bring a vast number of people who did not vote in 2014  to the pull for the first time.  -Finally, Brexit negotiating has been giving a lot of visibility to the European Union. All newspaper over Europe keep talking about the issue and try to forecast how it will end. Surprisingly, this might have brought a lot of publicity to the EU and made its institutions less passive and trivial to the eyes of the European Citizens. Sources:

While it is true that some issues, such as climate change and (above all) managing migrants flows motivate people to vote, it is also true that policies on such issues are still mostly implemented according to national legislation, and that the EU has been doing little, if anything, to help solving them. With that being said, the European Parliament has for this election put in extra effort to make sure that the voting turnout does not set a record low, with their campaign called 'This Time I'm Voting' (https://www.thistimeimvoting.eu/), providing EU citizens with extensive information about how and where to vote, as well as information about where to vote in the respective countries.

While voter turn-out in the European elections have been on a downwards trend, there is reason to believe that this will not continue with the 2019 election. Firstly, in response to the low voter turnout in 2014, the EU initiated the ‘this time I am voting campaign’ to increase awareness about EU elections and mobilize voter participation all across Europe (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/elections-press-kit/2/this-time-i-m-voting) . Secondly, the EU has featured as a major talking point across different European countries in the light of events such as Brexit and border closings. This could mean an increased interest in the EU and its work, whether as a supporter or a skeptic, and thereby an increased interest for potential voters to participate in EU elections (https://www.euronews.com/2019/02/12/european-election-2019-this-time-will-be-different). Moreover, the EU elections will be held in conjunction with local and regional elections in both Ireland and Spain, which could secure, and potentially increase, and already above-average voter turnout in these two countries (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/about-parliament/en/in-the-past/previous-elections). The UK will most likely not be voting in the European election, even if they were to extend the notification of article 50 (https://www.ft.com/content/901f95fe-1a70-11e9-9e64-d150b3105d2). As the UK voter turnout has been on the lower side, the overall average voter turnout will be positively influenced by this absence. However, there is still a chance that despite these variables, the voter turnout will continue its downward trend, and I therefore assign a 15% probability of that happening.

For instance, the recent local environmental movements in several European countries lend us to think that there will be more investment on such issues from the citizens, at the European level. Also, certain States such as Belgium, Spain and Lithuania have scheduled local/national elections on the same day as the European elections in order to give a boost to the participation rate (politico.eu). Finally, the EU Parliament — with the European Commission — has launched an awareness campaign, in particular aimed at the youth (deemed valuable in election times). In sum, there are strong indications that the voter turnout for the 2019 European Parliament elections will not supplant the record of 2014.  10% YES: However, one wants to keep a reserve, although small : 10% is for letting the doubt surface. The risk of foreign powers interfering in votes can also discourage Europeans from voting and giving their voice. Finally, on a pessimistic note, participation rates have steadily declined through the decades, so one could expect the elections of 2019 to take the turn on the elections of 2014 and set a record low.

The recent events and the current European context will surely boost the participation rate.
Indeed, the European Union is very questioned, but this state of affairs will not push towards abstention. On the contrary, eurosceptics through a protest vote will manifest this position very strongly. Eurosceptic partys take the vote more seriously than partys with a broader base. The Hungarian populists (turnout of 28.97% in Hungary) and Polish (turnout of 23.83% in Poland in 2014) will try to have a bigger place in the parliament and will therefore encourage their voters, always more numerous from day to day, to support them to overturn the pro-eu majority in the Parliament. Italians too will have a greater desire to express themselves with the advent of Salvini.
The protest voting theory also shows that voters use peripheral polls to punish the holders of central power in the home country (Mair 2004). In addition, in my opinion: The turnout will probably increase in France due to the very popular protest of the  « Gilets Jaunes » (theory of the protest vote here) but also with the strong support for euroscepticism (the Front National head polls for May 2019). The United Kingdom, in relation to Brexit, will surely not be counted, thus avoiding counting a country with a low turnout are. (But if the country remains in the EU this could push the setting of the record, because the British will not care to send elected in an organization in which they will leave, thus the abstention will be total). Croatia with one of the lowest rates of turnout, will surely see its rate increased, because the country was not even in the European Union for 1 year when the last European elections arrived. Since 2014, the Croats have, I think, developed a greater Europhilia or an Euroscepticism, but in any case they will have a need to express themselves, higher than before. The Eurobarometer shows that many Dutch people are ready to vote, with 55% of very likely to vote and 16% of likely, which contrasts with 2014 when the turnout was only 37%.

The overall question remains: whether voter apathy will maintain a steady decline of voter turn-out since 1979 (continuity), or contemporary political forces have and will rally voter turn-out (contingencies). Less than a third of Slovaks plan to vote in European elections A poll carried out by Focus agency on behalf of the Representation of the European Commission in Slovakia shows that 27 percent of the respondents want to participate in the European Parliamentary elections, while 8 percent are sure that they will not take part. However, political scientist Pavol Baboš notes that voter turnout promised in surveys and actual turnout on election day are two different things. "It's one thing to say yes in a poll and another to get up and vote on the day of the election," he said. According to Baboš, the reason why voter turnout will probably be lower is that the European elections will overlap with the presidential election, which will see a big campaign in the run-up to the vote. He pointed out that the presidential election will be followed by Easter, when most politicians do not actively participate in campaigning.

The voter turnout has declined with every European Parliament election, but the decline has flattened out in recent elections, and the difference in voter turnout between the previous two elections was very small, less than 1%. I can't speak for all European countries, but in Germany, voter turnout increased in all recent state and national elections, presumably due to the rise of the far right party which mobilised people who would not previously have voted, but on the other hand also people who would make sure to vote to counter the far right. I would argue that particularly in the more populous countries of Europe, politics have been very tumultous, or extreme, in the past few or couple of years, which means people in general are perhaps more aware and talking about politics than they would have a few years ago, and due to Brexit the same may be the case for EU politics. This may mean that more people have opinions on the EU and will bother to vote. So I doubt that voter turnout will be a record low, however, given an overall frustration with politics and/or the EU, feeling that the vote wouldn't matter, and lack of relatedness to the EU parliament, pariticularly in Eastern European countries, could still mean that a substantial number of people don't bother to vote.

Base Case is a 3.09% decline using historical data. Electoral turnout.

Since the election of the Members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage in 1979 participation in the European election has constantly decline. On average it was higher than 50% from 1979 (61.99%) to 1994 (56.61%). It was still close to 50% in 1999 (49.51%). Since then it has been below 50%, dropping from 45.7% in 2004 to 42.61% in 2014.
https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/european-issues/0491-european-elections-2019-what-will-the-new-parliament-s-composition-be Declining turnout As the EU engages in top-down efforts to enthuse voters, its starting position is that only half of Europe's adult population say they are interested in the election, according to the new Eurobarometer survey. That's on par with surveys conducted prior to the 2014 European Parliament election, in which turnout dropped for the seventh time in a row to less than 43 percent. In Slovakia just 13 percent voted.
https://www.politico.eu/article/european-election-2019-brussels-risks/ Election opinions If the survey results are anything to go by, the EU will have difficulty getting more people out to vote next year than they have in the past (turnout in the 2014 ballot was 42.6 percent, a record low).
